title: Is it right to start playing the guitar on a Flying V Gibson? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not really. I know that any decent guitar is good enough to learn on, but there’s a reason why the Flying V and similar V-bodies guitars won’t work as well. It’s not the best guitar in terms of ergonomics. First off, you really can’t play the Flying V sitting down, and if you’re practicing, you’re probably gonna be sitting down. Now, people will say that you can hook the groove of the V onto your leg. Yes that works, but the fact is that your fretting hand is still keeping the guitar up from falling. When you are learning, you want your hands and arms to be relaxed, and if your fretting hand is doing most of its work keeping a guitar upright, then that’s not relaxed and it’s not good for technique and posture. Now let’s consider playing standing up. It’s actually okay to learn this way, except it will tire you faster when you’re standing up. Again, not so much an issue, but when learning, you want to be relaxed and you want to conserve your energy. After all, you want to spend most of your energy on learning, not carrying a guitar. It is important to note though that depending on how high you strap on the guitar and the angle you use it, a person may find that the wing of the guitar may interfere with the picking forearm.

No, Flying V are beautifully guitars but hard to practice with… You always have to stand up and play that beauty… Maybe get it when you get a second guitar… Checkout Fender Stratocasters, they are very comfortable playing sitting down or standing up… They also come in many price ranges and you can get many different sounds from them… If you can't afford an American Stratocaster, go for a Mexican Stratocaster… I have one and she plays very well really close to an American Stratocaster… Only difference I see and hear is the American Stratocaster has better hardware… Best thing to do is go to a guitar store and play many different guitars and find one that feels and looks good to you… Once you find the one take to in store repair shop and have them check it out for you…make sure the neck is straight and that all the pickups, electronics, toggle switch and tuners are in good working… Once you buy have the repair shop set up and intonated, cost between $25-$50, usually comes with free strings… The set up deals with how high you want the strings to be… The intonation deals with proper tuning with the guitar… Have fun playing…
